awd_abstract_narration:
Data centers are crucial in the modern, Internet-based economy, and information technology companies need employees who have the skills to run a highly efficient and modern data center -- expertise in identity management, systems management, virtualization, storage, and networking. At the same time, there is a pressing need in the state of Florida to expand access in rural areas to high-demand occupational training, educational best practices, and state-of-the-art educational infrastructure. This project will increase the accessibility of technical education for rural and underserved Florida residents, with a focus on the skills needed to operate a modern data center. One product will be the curriculum for a new Network Enterprise Administration technical certificate. After students have completed this program of study, they will be eligible for a number of high-skill, high-wage, high-growth jobs, including Computer Network Architect, Computer Network Support Specialist, Computer Programmer, Computer Systems Analyst, Computer User Support Specialist, and Network and Computer Systems Administrator. Partners in this project include Florida State College at Jacksonville, Daytona State College, Eastern Florida State College, Seminole State College, Tallahassee Community College, and the National Convergence Technology Center (an Advanced Technological Education [ATE] national center). Fourteen business and industry partners will work with the educational institutions to develop the curriculum, train faculty, and provide opportunities for students.

This project builds on a prior NSF ATE grant (Award DUE-1104234, "iNoVATE: A Network Virtualization Project"), which resulted in the creation of a Network Virtualization technical certificate, over 100 community college faculty completing professional development in network virtualization, and over 100 students enrolled in newly developed network virtualization courses. The new project will create online curricula for five courses that align with the Microsoft Certified Solutions Expert (MCSE) server infrastructure certification, along with two additional courses, "Virtual Internship" and "Virtual Capstone." Major project activities include (1) designing, implementing, and disseminating the curriculum for the new Network Enterprise Administration technical certificate; (2) expanding Network Enterprise Administration labs, where students can remotely access equipment to practice server administration skills; (3) developing and offering workshops and other teaching resources for faculty; and (4) disseminating information about the Network Enterprise Administration program to rural and underserved areas. As online education becomes more common, it is imperative that distance learning students gain remote access to authentic, hands-on learning opportunities. Therefore, the project will build on prior research to explore the impact of remote access to virtual lab activities and other authentic, work-based learning, including student internships and capstone course requirements. The project team will measure and track student knowledge construction and the development of discipline-specific problem-solving skills for statistical comparison and longitudinal analysis, improving project strategies and building a strong foundation for future research.

por.por_cntn:
The iNoVATE-X project made some difference in students’ computer literacy knowledge. The most considerable pre-post difference on correct responses was seen for questions asking about ‘primary language for building websites,’ and ‘factors that control webpage load speed.’ Students did not learn the definition of Mbps.

The iNoVATE-X project had an impact on high school students’ interest in studying IT when they go to college. On average, high students indicated there was more than a 75% chance they would attend college, and 50% of high school students attending the summer camps said they were interested in studying IT, computer science, or computer engineering in college. Most of the high school students (86%) reported that at least one person had spoken to them about pursuing computer science or computer engineering. The most frequently cited individuals were family members and the tech/computer instructors at the camp.

In addition to impacting high school students’ computer literacy knowledge and interest in studying IT in college, the iNoVATE-X project also had a significant impact on undergraduate students’ content knowledge on server configuration and administration.

Results show that there were 589 students enrolled in the Server Configuration and Server Administration courses from 2016 to 2019. During the 2018 – 2019 academic year, an average of 37% of students identified as members of a racially or ethnically diverse group (Hispanic, African American, or American Indians). Although the percentage of men remained higher than women, the program had an increase of women from 16% to an average of 22.2%. The age of students during the Fall 2018 courses was 20 – 38 years old. This age group comprised 75% of students. During the Spring 2019 semester, students between 16 – 27 years old made up 52% of the population, while students between the age of 28 – 40 made up 35% of the student population.

Furthermore, the project influenced students’ perceptions of their problem-solving confidence, control, and approach. Overall, on the post-survey of students during the Spring 2018 semester, all students showed positive attitudes toward problem-solving confidence, control, approach, and avoidance (with averages of more than 3.0). Students who indicated having multiple ethnicities showed higher avoidance tendencies than other student groups.

There were significant differences among the ethnicity groups on the confidence and personal control subscales. On the confidence scale, African American students scored similarly to students who identified themselves as Asian Pacific Islanders. But, African American students had lower confidence ratings than the other ethnic groups. On the personal control subscale, Hispanic and students with multiple ethnicities scored higher than Asian-Pacific Islander and White students. African American students were in the middle, scoring similarly to all groups on the personal control subscale.

During the Spring 2018 semester, thirty-six undergraduate students completed the content-based server configuration questionnaire measure before the course, and 17 students completed this questionnaire after the course. Most students were men (34), while the remaining ten were women. Overall, students scored an average of 10.68 out of 13 on the knowledge questions. Pre- and post-course accuracy scores were not significantly different (M = 10.67 and 10.71, respectively), and accuracy did not vary by gender (M = 10.63 for females, 10.71 for males).

In summary, overall, the iNoVATE-X project had a significant impact on high school students’ attitudes towards IT and computer science literacy. The project positively affected college students’ knowledge of server configuration, problem-solving perceptions, and perspectives about learning in a virtual environment.

The detailed analysis of post-survey responses after four years of Working Connection professional development sessions reveal the significant impact that the project had on community college faculty. Overwhelming, in each year after the Working Connections professional development, community college faculty indicated increases in their IT skills through engaging in hands-on activities. Community college faculty also indicated using iNoVATE-X course materials to create or modify numerous courses at their colleges. 

The impact of the iNoVATE-X project was facilitated through long-term partnerships between businesses, industry, and community college faculty. The project has years of evidence of consistent and meaningful engagement of stakeholders over the life of the project. The iNoVATE-X leadership team of Principal and Co-Principal Investigators sustained strategic alliances across diverse stakeholder groups to ensure student success. The project leadership team committed to and successfully developed a Network Virtualization certification track that provides students with technology experiences to secure high wage jobs in the technology workforce. The efforts of the iNoVATE-X leadership team and key stakeholders should be replicated to generate success for more community college students interested in securing high-wage jobs in the IT and 21st-century technology-based workforce. In sum, the iNoVATE-X project team accomplished all the goals and objectives set forth and outlined in the funded proposal.

Last Modified: 10/01/2020
Modified by: Ernest Friend
